citeinfo.title: Congressional District Boundaries for New Jersey, 2012 - 2022
citeinfo.othercit: The data and map were formally approved and released by the Redistricting Commission at its December 23, 2011 meeting in Trenton, NJ.

descript.abstract:
This shapefile delineates the US Congressional District boundaries in New Jersey, 2012 - 2022. It was created by the New Jersey Redistricting Commission, 2011 Congressional Commission, based on geographic and demographic data from the US Census Bureau, 2010 census.
Members of the 2011 Congressional Commission:
13th member John Farmer, Jr. , Chairman. Mr. Farmer was chosen by the 12 original commissioners.
Democrats Michael Baker (Delegation Vice-Chair) Nilsa Cruz-Perez Edward Farmer Jeannine Frisby LaRue Joseph Roberts, Jr. (Delegation Chairman) Philip Thigpen
Republicans Caroline Casagrande Michael DuHaime (Delegation Chairman) Sherine El-Abd Aubrey Fenton Eric Jaso M. Susan Sheppard
descript.purpose: The data and map were created to re-apportion representation of the citizens of New Jersey in the United States House of Representatives, following the 2010 decennial census. These districts apply to the election of U.S. Representatives from New Jersey beginning in 2012 with the election of the 113th Congress.
descript.supplinf:
The original map data were received in Geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude.) These were re-projected by OGIS to NAD83 NJ State Plane feet. Shapefiles in both coordinate systems are available.
Please note that the US Census Bureau TIGER shapefile municipal boundary data (Minor Civil Divisions aka MCD), upon which these shapefiles were based in part, differ geographically from the municipal boundary data published by NJOIT - OGIS. Please keep this in mind if attempting to overlay the district boundaries and municipal boundaries.

cntperp.cntorg: NJ Office of Legislative Services, Central Management Unit - State Government

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata

dataqual.complete: In this redistricting, New Jersey is losing one district due to slower population growth in New Jersey than in some other states. For the 112th Congress, New Jersey had 13 districts; beginning with the 2012 elections, New Jersey will have 12 districts, all of which are shown in this shapefile.

horizpa.horizpar: Positional accuracy is based on the 2010 TIGER data for municipal boundaries and census blocks.
